newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan state firm to set up branch in HK.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan state firm to set up branch in HK.

text.p: Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecommunication Corp said on Monday it would set up an office in Hong Kong on August 1.
The move would make Chunghwa Taiwan's first state-run firm to form a presence in Hong Kong since the former British colony's return to China on July 1.

Chunghwa said its branch would be a one-person liaison office that uses Hong Kong as a hub to seek investments in other Southeast Asian countries -- but not investments in Hong Kong or mainland China.

"We feel it is better to seek telecom investments in Southeast Asian countries from Hong Kong because those countries traditionally have greater telecom links with Hong Kong than with Taipei," a Chunghwa spokesman told Reuters by telephone.
"Our office in Hong Kong will be a liaison office and will not be involved in operations," he said.
Chunghwa said it was considering investments particularly in Thailand, Vietnam, Burma, Indonesia and Malaysia.

The spokesman, who declined to be named, said the state-run company would not seek to invest in mainland China because Taiwan's government has not lifted its ban on direct telecommunications with communist Beijing.
"We are a state-run firm and we have to follow government polices," he said.
Chunghwa in July began allowing customers to use their mobile telephones in China by adding the mainland to Taiwan's "international roaming" network.
But the company said its liberalisation did not amount to a lifting of the ban on cross-Strait direct links because all connections had to be routed through a third territory.

Taiwan has banned direct connections with China since they split after a civil war in 1949. But Taipei has said it would allow Hong Kong to continue its function as a middleman between Taiwan and China after the July 1 handover.
Chunghwa said telecom investments in Hong Kong would be impractical because the market was already saturated.
"There are already so many telecom companies with long-established operations in Hong Kong that even if we were authorised to invest, we would be killed," the spokesman said.
